title: Percy Grant (Royal Navy officer)
text:
<a href="Admiral%20%28Royal%20Navy%29">Admiral</a> Sir Edmund Percy Fenwick George Grant, (23 September 1867 – 8 September 1952) was a <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> officer who served as <a href="Chief%20of%20Navy%20%28Australia%29">First Naval Member and Chief of the Australian Naval Staff</a> from 1919 to 1921.
Naval career.
Grant saw service in the <a href="Anglo-Egyptian%20War%20%281882%29">Egyptian War</a> of 1882 as well as the <a href="Revolta%20da%20Armada">Brazilian Naval Mutiny</a> in 1893. He was promoted to <a href="Lieutenant%20%28navy%29">lieutenant</a> on 1 October 1890, posted as a lieutenant for navigation on the <a href="battleship">battleship</a> , and promoted to <a href="Commander%20%28Royal%20Navy%29">commander</a> (Navigation) on 26 June 1902. In September 1902 he was posted to for study at the <a href="Royal%20Naval%20College%2C%20Greenwich">Royal Naval College</a>.
He went on to serve during the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a> initially as <a href="flag%20captain">flag captain</a> to Vice Admiral <a href="Lewis%20Bayly%20%28Royal%20Navy%20officer%29">Sir Lewis Bayly</a> in and then as flag captain and chief of staff to Admiral <a href="Cecil%20Burney">Sir Cecil Burney</a> who was then second-in-command of the <a href="Grand%20Fleet">Grand Fleet</a>. In that capacity he saw his ship <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>ed and crippled at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Jutland">Battle of Jutland</a> in 1916. 
After the war he was appointed <a href="Chief%20of%20Navy%20%28Australia%29">First Naval Member and Chief of the Australian Naval Staff</a>. In this role, he served as defence advisor to <a href="Billy%20Hughes">Billy Hughes</a>, <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Australia">Prime Minister of Australia</a> at the Empire Conference in <a href="London">London</a> in 1921. He was appointed Admiral Superintendent at <a href="HMNB%20Portsmouth">Portsmouth Dockyard</a> in 1922 and retired in 1928. He was recalled during the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a> to serve as Captain at the <a href="Port%20of%20Holyhead">Port of Holyhead</a>.
